title: If It’s Happened to the Nationals, Ryan Zimmerman Has Lived It
text:
WASHINGTON—After fall workouts in September 2005, players from the University of Virginia baseball team often trekked 120 miles north on U.S. Route 29 from Charlottesville to Washington. They embarked on that journey to watch Ryan Zimmerman, the first draft pick in Nationals history who just three months earlier had battled alongside them in the NCAA tournament.

As Zimmerman’s friends traveled up the road, they noticed something outside the window that left them stunned: freshly minted billboards with Zimmerman’s face plastered on them, heralding him far more than the typical rookie. Sean Doolittle, a Virginia pitcher who is now a Nationals reliever, remembers the trips well.

“Here he was,” Doolittle said, “being anointed the face of this new franchise.”

Fourteen years later, that description remains true. Zimmerman never left Washington, appearing for the Nationals in every season of their existence following their relocation from Montreal. He lasted through two general managers, seven field managers and two home ballparks. He saw the up-and-down tenure of Jayson Werth, the hype surrounding Stephen Strasburg and Bryce Harper. He survived seven straight seasons that ended before the playoffs and endured the heartbreak of four embarrassing early October exits. If it happened to the Nationals, Zimmerman lived it.

But now Zimmerman, 35 years old and approaching free agency, finds himself in an unprecedented position that he feared might never arrive: preparing for a long-awaited World Series. It’s the first involving an entrant from the city of Washington since the Senators fell to the New York Giants in 1933. The Nationals earned their place there by sweeping the St. Louis Cardinals out of the National League Championship Series in front of a delirious sellout crowd Tuesday night.

Finally, the Nationals gave Mr. National a team worthy of that name.

“A lot of people play for as long as I have and don’t get a chance to do this, so I still consider myself pretty lucky,” Zimmerman said. “But it definitely makes it a little bit sweeter.”

Injuries prevented Zimmerman from fulfilling his full potential, most notably the shoulder condition that forced him to move across the diamond to first base in 2015. He averaged 92 games from 2014 through 2019. Despite that, he owns a lifetime batting average of .279, to go along with 270 home runs and 1,015 RBIs. Jim Riggleman, Zimmerman’s manager from 2009 to 2011, insists that a healthy Zimmerman “would have been a candidate for the Hall of Fame.”

He looks healthy now, fully capable of helping the Nationals. He went 9-for-31 (.290) with five RBIs from the wild card game through the NLCS. On the field after the final out Tuesday, managing principal owner Mark Lerner made sure that Zimmerman touched the NLCS trophy first.

“We couldn’t have a finer individual representing the Nats,” Lerner said.

Washington Nationals manager Dave Martinez and Ryan Zimmerman celebrate after Game 4 of the NLCS. Photo: Patrick Semansky/Associated Press

The Nationals held the fourth overall draft pick in 2005 and knew they couldn’t afford to miss. The player they chose needed to invigorate a new fan base in a jilted market that lost the second incarnation of the Senators in 1972. A bust could’ve derailed the trajectory of the club in its infancy.

In a class of future stars that included Ryan Braun, Troy Tulowitzki and Andrew McCutchen, Nationals GM Jim Bowden thought other available players had more upside than Zimmerman. Zimmerman felt like the safest option, a prospect all but certain to pan out, if not excel. Bowden predicted a .280 average, 20 homers and Gold Glove-caliber defense at third. It didn’t hurt that Zimmerman grew up in Virginia Beach, Va., adding a hometown element to the selection.

“He was the lowest risk baseball-wise,” Bowden said. “We knew this was the guy we could build around, a ‘cover of the yearbook and media guide’ guy.”

Zimmerman justified Bowden’s confidence in him. He drove in 110 runs in his first full season in 2006, followed by a 91-RBI campaign in 2007. In 2008, Zimmerman christened Nationals Park on its opening night by slamming a walk-off home run, one of his 15 walk-off hits, more than any active player other than Albert Pujols.

Unfortunately, almost nobody else on the roster provided much support. The Nationals were bad at the beginning, bottoming out with just 59 wins in 2008 and 2009. Manny Acta, the manager from 2007 into 2009, said that “at times, we felt it was Zim and the rest.”

The struggles didn’t stop Zimmerman from committing to the Nationals. In April 2009, he signed a $45 million extension that bought out two years of free agency. Then in February 2012, before the Nationals ever finished with a record above .500 and two years before he hit the open market, Zimmerman signed a $100 million deal that linked player and team forever.

Tom Hagan, his teammate at Virginia and now one of his representatives at Creative Artists Agency, said Zimmerman “knew they were building something special.”

“There was never another choice,” Zimmerman said. “It was a no-brainer for me to stay here.”

The Nationals rewarded Zimmerman’s faith by showing the fruits of their rebuild. Because of their ineptitude, the Nationals secured the first overall draft pick twice, in 2009 and 2010. It came at the right time: They landed Strasburg and Harper in consecutive Junes, giving Zimmerman pieces worth putting around him.

And on Oct. 1, 2012, an Atlanta loss clinched the Nationals’ first division title. When the news reached the dugout in Washington, Zimmerman threw his head back, raised his arms and let out a scream.

“I took that as total release for him after all the losing,” said Bob Carpenter, the Nationals’ television play-by-play announcer since 2006.

The release quickly turned into another form of frustration, as the Nationals commenced to lose in the division series four times, developing into the sport’s most notorious chokers. Managers came and went, from Davey Johnson to Matt Williams to Dusty Baker to Dave Martinez. They wouldn’t shed that reputation until this season, when, despite starting a dismal 19-31, they rebounded to claim an NL wild-card spot and storm through the playoffs.

Ryan Zimmerman will be a free agent after the season but wants to remain in Washington. Photo: Rob Carr/Getty Images

Hagan says Zimmerman wants to continue playing after this season, preferably a 16th year with the Nationals, who will almost certainly decline his $18 million option for 2020. But that doesn’t concern Zimmerman right now. Four victories separate the face of the franchise from a World Series championship, the ultimate prize the Nationals believe he deserves.

“I was 20 years old when I got here. We were not very good,” Zimmerman said. “Me, the fans, the community are kind of one, and they deserve this just as much as we do.”

Write to Jared Diamond at jared.diamond@wsj.com
description: Ryan Zimmerman survived seven straight seasons that ended before the playoffs and endured the heartbreak of four embarrassing early October exits. If it happened to the Nationals, he lived it.
